newsitem.title: USA: Actor Tim Allen faces Michigan drunk driving charge.
newsitem.headline: Actor Tim Allen faces Michigan drunk driving charge.

text.p: A not guilty plea was entered on behalf of actor Tim Allen during a court proceeding Wednesday on a drunk driving charge after a Memorial Day weekend arrest, a court spokesman said.

Allen, star of the popular television sitcom "Home Improvement" and of several movies, did not appear in Bloomfield Township's 48th District Court. The 43-year-old Michigan native was arrested in suburban Detroit Saturday night after he was caught going 70 miles-per-hour in a 40 mph zone in his 1988 Ferrari.

Police said Allen also failed a sobriety test. "The sobriety tests were given that indicated ... there was a probability that drinking was involved with driving," Bloomfield Township Police Capt. James Anas said.

"Due to the pending court action we cannot make any comment at this time," Michael Novak, Allen's attorney, told Reuters. Novak said Allen's plea was made by letter and Allen did not have to appear in court.
Allen, whose real name is Timothy Alan Dick, was scheduled to appear at a pre-trial conference June 25. He was held briefly and released after his attorney posted a $100 bond.

A first offence for drunk driving carries penalties that include community service, jail time, up to $500 in fines and a 30-day license suspension. Allen's publicist told local newspapers the actor was in Baltimore filming a movie.
Allen got his start as a comedian and became famous for a routine about men's fascination with power tools. He served 28 months in prison for selling cocaine in 1978.
